Carmelo B. es un humilde trabajador, que proviene de una familia sencilla que le enseñó el importante valor del trabajo. Carmelo se desempeña como mecánico, actividad que le ha dado el sustento durante 20 años.

Es soltero y tiene 2 hijos varones de 9 y 8 años por los cuales el trabaja arduamente, tanto para darles el sustento diario así como darles un buen ejemplo y que en un futuro sean personas de bien. Gracias a la dedicación a su trabajo pudo independizarse, ya que éste empezó como ayudante.

Desea en un futuro poder poner un taller de mecánica. Pero por el momento dará seguridad a su casa de habitación, construyendo un muro que le pueda dar seguridad y protegerlo de la delicuencia que vive el barrio Hialeah donde éste habita.

loans.use: Building a wall in her house.

loans.name: Fialuma

texts.en:
Fialuma S., 51, is married with 3 children. She has many years of experience in the Taro and banana business. She sells her produce to her friends, relatives, and the local community. Also, during the harvest season she supplies the public market with produce 2 days per week.

Fialuma has had 2 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (~104 USD). SPBD loans are Fialuma’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan will support her kids at school and her church contribution. Her husband also helps to operate the business.

loans.use: To purchase gromozone chemicals, sting chemicals, a weedkiller sprayer machine, shovels, a bushknife, claves, and wire for a fence.

loans.name: Gloria Concepción

texts.es:
Gloria, 26, has a high-school education. She's the single mother of 2 young children, both of whom depend on her, and they live in the Peruvian "region" of Puno. She makes a living selling bed sheets and candy. However, she only sells candy on Sundays because she doesn't earn much from it. Selling sheets, on the other hand, generates more income because she brings them from the city of Cuzco. Her businesses have grown from the first loans that she received from the 3 de mayo (May 3) community bank, something very pleasing for her.

With this S/.1000 (1000 Peruvian soles) loan, to be repaid in 4 months, Gloria will buy 30 sets of sheets that she will bring from Cuzco herself for sell locally.

Gloria's dream is is to have a wholesale grocery and study for a career that will help her grow her business and educate her 2 children.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Gloria Concepción, tiene 26 años de edad, concluyó su secundaria, es madre soltera de 2 hijos, que dependen de ella, viven en el distrito de Ilave en Jr. 28 de julio Nº 951 de la provincia El Collao, de la región de Puno. Ella se dedica al negocio de venta de sabanas y venta de golosinas, las golosinas sólo los comercializa los días domingos porque no le genera mucha ganancia, en cambio la comercialización de sábanas sí le genera más ingreso, porque los lleva a la ciudad de Cusco. Estos negocios los incrementó con los primeros préstamos que adquirió del Banco Comunal 3 de mayo y por esto se siente feliz.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000.00 nuevos soles, el cual cancelará en 4 meses, comprará 30 Juegos de sabanas que llevará directamente a la ciudad de Cusco para ponerlas en venta.

Su mayor sueño es tener una tienda Mayorista de Abarrotes y estudiar una carrera técnica el cual le ayude en sus negocios y poder educar a sus 2 hijos.

loans.use: Buy merchandise for resale.

loans.name: José Bismarck

texts.es:
José Bismarck lives in the neighborhood 3-80 of Managua, a poor area lacking basic necessities such as a sewage system. José is married and has a 6 year old son, whom he has to watch over, especially his health.

As a result, José Bismarck needs a loan to install a sewage system in his house. Currently, José deposits the sewage in the patio or in the street like the rest of his neighbors, but this is a problem because the sewage brings disease.

Two years ago, José Bismarck began working as a solicitor for a private company. During these two years he has been able to improve his house and hopes to continue working so that he can offer the best to his son.

Translated from Spanish by Jordan Shanker, Kiva volunteer.

José Bismarck habita en el barrio 3-80 de Managua, un barrio pobre y carente de servicios básicos como aguas negras. José es casado y tiene un pequeño de 6 años, por el cual tiene que velar y sobre todo garantizar salud.

Es por eso que José Bismarck necesita el préstamo porque quiere invertir en la instalación de aguas negras en su casa de habitación, ya que actualmente las aguas residuales las tiene que regar en el patio o regarla en la calle al igual que todos sus vecinos, y esto es un problema para su familia ya que esto conlleva enfermedades.

José Bismarck desde hace 2 años se ha venido desempeñando com gestor de cobro en una empresa privada. Y durante estos dos años ha venido mejorando su casa, y espera poder tener siempre trabajo para darle lo lo mejor a su hijo.

loans.use: Install an in-house sewage system

loans.name: Pulaloa

texts.en:
Pulaloa T., 55, is married with 10 children. She has many years of experience in her business. She runs a bakery where she makes and sells donuts, pancakes and snacks. She sells to the local community and relatives. She also shops her goods around town 5 days per week.

Pulaloa has had 2 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (~104 USD). SPBD loans are Pulaloa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will support her kids at school and her church contributions. Her husband also operates the business.

loans.use: To purchase new stock and equipment for her business, including: a new stove, a set of bowls, a set of chinese pots, cooking oil, sacks of flour, sugar, and baking powder

loans.name: Teofila

texts.es:
Teofila, 40, only has a fifth-grade education. She's married and has three children, two boys and a girl who are still in school. They own their house in the Peruvian town of Chimbo. She used to earn a living selling cigarettes, a business that ultimately failed, but then switched to selling shampoo which she hauls from Desaguadero (on the Peruvia-Bolivian border) to the Peruvian city of Arequipa. She also earns income raising bulls.

Teofila belongs to the Central Progreso community bank where she first received a S/.300 (300 Peruvian soles) loan to buy 6 cases of shampoo. She's now earning a living raising bulls. With this S/.2300 loan, to be repaid in 4 installments, she will buy two bulls. As for her husband, he set up a shop in Lima to make clothing.

Teofila is very grateful for the loan that helped her to improve her business, learn to be responsible and hard-working. Her ultimate goal is to have a business in Lima making clothes.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Teofila tiene 40 años de edad, logró estudiar hasta el quinto grado de primaria es casada y tienen tres hijos, dos varones una mujercita, quienes se encuentran estudiando, ellos cuenta con una vivienda propia en el centro poblado de Chimbo. Anteriormente se dedicaba a la venta de cigarros, negocio que fracasó y luego cambió de giro para dedicarse a la venta de champú en sachet, que lo lleva desde Desaguadero a Arequipa, paralelamente se dedica al engorde de toros.

Ella pertenece al banco comunal “Central Progreso” donde se inició con un crédito de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles que lo invirtió en 6 cajas de champú en sachet. Actualmente se dedica al engorde de toros. Con este préstamo de S/. 2,300.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará dos toros. Por otro lado, su esposo instaló una tienda de confección de ropa en la ciudad de Lima.

La señora Teofila está muy agradecida con el crédito que le ayudo a mejorar su negocio, aprendió a ser responsable y muy trabajadora. El anhelo que ella tiene es tener una empresa de confección de ropa esto en la ciudad de Lima.

loans.use: Buy livestock.

loans.name: Mualua

texts.en:
Mualua M., 28, is married with 2 children. She has many years of experience in the Taxi Service business. She serves the general public 7 days per week.

Maula has had no previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD). SPBD loans are Mualua’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use the loan to buy tires and other car parts for her taxi.

Her husband also runs a business.

loans.use: The loan will be used to purchase tires and other car parts.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.es:
Teresa is a single mother, and despite having been through some very difficult moments as consequence of leaving her husband, she had the will and courage to move forward. Thanks to her parents, Teresa can work while her mother takes care of her daughter. Nevertheless, the salary of a teacher in Peru is insufficient to cover the needs of the family. As a result, one year ago, Teresa started to embroider blankets and dresses typical to the mountains in her spare time.

To ensure that this activity gives her higher income, she wants to be able to grow her business and establish a workshop in her house, where she can devote time to her embroidery and increase her orders for better income. To be able to install a workshop she needs $200, money that she asks for as a loan to invest in improving her workshop and as a result, cover household costs. She hopes that your answer will be favorable so that she can continue moving forward.

Translated from Spanish to English by Laura Jung, Kiva volunteer.

Teresa, es madre soltera y a pesar de haber pasado por momentos muy difíciles a consecuencia del abandono de su pareja tuvo la valentía y coraje de salir adelante, gracias a sus padres puede trabajar mientras su madre se queda al cuidado de su hija. Sin embargo el sueldo de una profesora en nuestro país es insuficiente para cubrir las necesidades dentro de la familia, por ello que doña Teresa empezó hace un año a dedicarse al bordado de mantas y costuras típicas de la sierra, lo que realiza en sus tiempos libres, al ver que esta actividad le deja grandes ganancias tiene el deseo de poder hacer crecer su negocio y poder implementar un taller dentro de su casa, donde pueda dar a conocer su trabajo y aumentar sus pedidos para mejorar sus ingresos económicos. Para poder implementar su taller requiere de 500 soles, dinero que le solicita en calidad de préstamo para invertirlo en la mejorar su taller y así poder solventar los gastos dentro de su casa. Ella espera que su respuesta sea favorable para poder seguir adelante.

loans.use: To establish an embroidery workshop in her home because her salary as a teacher is not enough.

loans.name: Andrés

texts.es:
Andres is a devoted father of a family and very hard worker. He shows it everyday on his farm, investing a lot of time in improving his production and harvesting fruits to sell in the markets. Without a doubt, all of his work has a purpose, which is to be able to have better income so that he can keep up with the education costs for his children, who attend high school in the capitol, Lima.

They are the reason that Andres desires to improve his production and invest in more coffee plants, bananas, and other diverse fruits that are profitable in the area. Andres wants to be able to transport the same fruits to sell in other nearby cities. For this he asks for a loan of $375, money that he guarantees will be invested in, and of great help to, his production. He hopes, with all his heart that, you can help this humble father who wants only the best for his children.

Translated from Spanish to English by Laura Jung, Kiva volunteer

Andrés es un entregado padre de familia y empeñoso trabajador, lo demuestra todos los días en sus terrenos de cultivo, invierte gran tiempo en la mejora de su producción y en la cosecha de frutos para vender en los mercados. Sin duda todo este trabajo tiene un propósito, el cual es poder tener mayores ingresos para que pueda solventar los gastos de sus hijos quienes cursan estudios superiores en la capital, Lima. Son por estas razones que Andrés tiene el deseo de mejorar su producción e invertir en mayores plantaciones de café, plátano y otras diversidades de frutas que son rentables en la zona. Andrés desea poder trasladar él mismo a otras ciudades cercanas sus productos para venderlos. Por ello solicita un préstamo de 1000 soles, dinero que le garantiza será debidamente invertido y de gran ayuda para su producción, esperamos de todo corazón que usted pueda ayudar a este humilde padre que desea lo mejor para sus hijos.

loans.use: Captial to invest in expanding his sales of fruit to nearby cities in the area.

loans.name: Rasela

texts.en:
Rasela T., 26, is married with 1 child. She has many years of experience in the Banana Plantation business. She sells to the general public and to villagers 2 days per week.

Rasela has had previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD). SPBD loans are Rasela’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She is the mother of one child, but her husband is unemployed. He is not supporting her by running a business. Therefore, this business is very important to the family.

loans.use: The loan will be used to purchase pesticides

loans.name: Pedro

texts.es:
Pedro is 37 years old and is very dedicated to his work as a farmer. He cultivates coffee, and now has a large quantity of plants in his nursery to plant later in the land. He hopes that his work with help him accomplish his dream that he so anxiously awaits, like getting married and starting a family. For this, he wants to increase production of plants, and save money in order to offer his future family a home with all the basic needs and comforts, so that his future children can grow in a harmonious environment filled with love. To accomplish these goals, he wants to purchase new coffee plants and requires your help to do it. Pedro needs $300 to buy the plants with the fertilizer they need. We hope that you can help Pedro to achieve his goals in the economic and personal sphere.

Translated from Spanish to English by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer

Pedro de 37 años es un hombre muy dedicado a su labor dentro de la agricultura, él cultiva café, ahora tiene una gran cantidad de plantas en su vivero para luego sembrarlas en sus terrenos. El desea que su actividad le ayude ha alcanzar los sueños que espera tan ansiosamente, como son; casarse y formar una familia. Por ello, desea incrementar la producción de sus cultivos ahorrar dinero y ofrecer a su futura familia un hogar con todas las necesidades básicas y comodidades para que sus futuros hijos puedan crecer en un ambiente armonioso y lleno de amor. Para ello, desea adquirir nuevas plantaciones de café y requiere de su apoyo para lograrlo, la suma que solicita es de 800 soles, necesarios para la compra de estas plantaciones y para su respectivo abono. Esperamos que usted pueda ayudar a Pedro a lograr concretar sus metas en el ámbito económico y personal.

loans.use: To purchase new coffee plants and their necessary fertilizers.

loans.name: Edith Xiomara

texts.es:
Edith lives in the Managua neighborhood of Unidad de Proposito ("Unity of Purpose"). She's 41-years old, married, and has a 12-year old son. Her husband is is a sales executive at a poultry business and contributes to the family's expenses.

Edith operates a general store. She started with loans and now has three-years experience running the business. The money that she's asked for is to be invested in merchandise for the general store. For the future, she wants to grow her business, improve her house and educate her son.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Doña Edith habita en el barrio Unidad de Propósito, tiene 41 años de edad, es casada, y tiene un hijo de 12 años de edad, su esposo trabaja de ejecutivo de ventas en una empresa de venta de pollos y aporta a los gastos del hogar.

La Sra. Edith tiene una pulpería con tres años de experiencia, e inicio con préstamos, con el dinero que esta solicitando es para invertirlo en capital de trabajo para la pulpería en variedades y productos para ofrecer siempre a sus clientes sus variedades. A futuro es hacer más grande el negocio, mejorar su vivienda y educar a sus hijos.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for AFODENIC - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Neidy Scarleth

texts.es:
Neidy, 29, lives in Managua's Laureles Norte neighborhood. She's married and has three children, 3, 5 and 8 years old. Her husband is a teacher at a secondary school and shares household expenses.

Neidy sells gold-laminated and silver jewelry pieces. She started the business four years ago with her own funds. She's applying for a loan to build a kitchen for her house, something that will greatly increase the comfort of her family. Her plans are to set up a general store in her house and to provide for the education of her children.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La Sra. Neydi tiene 29 años de edad, habita en el barrio Laureles Norte, es casada y tiene tres hijos de 3, 5 y 8 años de edad, su esposo es docente de secundaria y aporta a los gastos del hogar.

Doña Neidy vende prendas de oro laminado y plata , tiene cuatro años de experiencia, e inició con fondos propios, con el préstamo solicitado es para invertirlo en infraestructura en la construcción de la cocina de su casa para estar mas cómoda con su familia. Sus planes son poner una tienda de variedades en su casa, y cuidar de la educación de sus hijos.

loans.use: Build a kitchen.

loans.name: Perci

texts.es:
Ever since creating a family, Perci has devoted himself to satisfying the needs of his home. Thanks to successfully obtaining a motorcycle, he can work regularly and with joy thanks to being able to bring bread home daily, and moreover, being able to educate his children. Because his work is very demanding due to the hours invested in driving all over the city, Perci would like to increase his work by buying another motorcycle that he can rent out and manage in order to obtain better earnings. The amount that is required to buy a new vehicle is $200, money that he does not have right now, but asks for as a loan with the hope that he can count on your economic support as his business grows.

Translated from Spanish to English by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer

Perci desde que consolidó su familia se entregó por entero a poder satisfacer las necesidades dentro de su hogar. Gracias a que logró adquirir un motocarro, puede trabajar con normalidad y con mucha alegría, porque gracias a su trabajo puede llevar un pan diario a su hogar y sobre todo tener la posibilidad de educar a sus hijos. A pesar de que su trabajo es muy sacrificado por las horas invertidas manejando por toda la ciudad, Perci desea multiplicar su trabajo comprando una moto más, la cual pueda alquilar y administrar para obtener mayores ganancias, el monto que requiere para adquirir esta nueva movilidad es de 500 soles, dinero con el que por ahora no cuenta, pero lo solicita como préstamo con la esperanza de poder encontrar en usted un apoyo para crecer económicamente.

loans.use: To purchase an additional motorcycle to rent out and improve income to sustain his family.

loans.name: Marcelino

texts.es:
Marcelino is father of 4 children who attend school. For them, Marcelo has to keep moving forward despite the loss of his truck, which he had to give up after having been assaulted last month when he was working in transport. Marcelo has showed his courage and integrity and that he has the ability to keep going and not become discouraged, on the contrary, he will continue working as a famer, and help his family solve and recuperate from their present financial crisis. For these reasons, Marcelo is requesting a loan to invest in his land and to purchase a new truck to continue farming and with your help return to working in public transportation.

Translated from Spanish to English by Laura Jung, Kiva volunteer.

Marcelino es padre de 4 hijos quienes aún son escolares, por ellos, don Marcelo tiene que salir adelante a pesar de la perdida de su motocarro, que tuvo que sobrellevar al haber sido asaltado el mes pasado, él se dedicaba al transporte en moto. Pero don Marcelo nos mostró su valor y entereza que tuvo al poder salir adelante y no desanimarse, sino todo lo contrario, seguir adelante en su labor como agricultor, el cual le ayudará a poder solventar a su familia y recuperarse de la crisis económica que está pasando. Es por estas razones que solicita un préstamo de dinero que invertirá en sus cultivos y en la compra de un motocarro nuevo para seguir adelante trabajando en la agricultura y con su ayuda podría nuevamente también trabajar en el transporte público.

loans.use: To invest in his farmland and to buy a car to continue public transport in addition to farming.

loans.name: Teena

texts.en:
Teena M., 27, is married with 2 children. She has 6 years of experience in the Cattle Farm business. She sells to the village and the public 6 days per week. She has never had a loan with SPBD in the past.

Teena expects her weekly net cash flow to be 1000 Tala (~416 USD). SPBD loans are Teena’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use the loan to purchase barbed wires and nails for her farm.

loans.use: To purchase barbed wires and nails for the farm

loans.name: Juan

texts.es:
Juan is father of 5 children who are he adores. Due to separation from his wife three years ago, a situation that was difficult to overcome, Juan makes the effort, especially for his children who miss their mom. He cannot be with his children as much as he would like, but by working he tries to satisfy their needs. Juan started a call center business for the population, who are very appreciative of the service they receive from Juan, and he happily tends the calls of his neighbors.

Nevertheless, he plans to open a store where, among other things, he will install a speaker-phone to provide services to the rest of his neighbors. In order to do this, he requires a loan of $375 that he is asking of you, hoping to appeal to you good heart. He hopes that you are the person in whom Juan has so much hope.

Translated from Spanish to English by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer.

Don Juan es padre de 5 hijos quienes son su adoración, debido a la separación con su esposa hace más de 3 años, situación que fue difícil de superar sobre todo por sus pequeños hijos a quienes extraña y por quienes se esfuerza, no puede estar con ellos tanto como quisiera, pero con su trabajo trata de satisfacer las necesidades de ellos. Juan inició un negocio al servicio de los pobladores, quienes se encuentran muy agradecidos por la atención que reciben de parte de Juan quien muy alegremente atiende las llamadas de sus vecinos. Pero sin embargo, tiene planes de abrir una tienda donde, a la par, instalar un locutorio y así ampliar su servicio a los demás vecinos. Pero para esto, requiere de un préstamo de 1000 soles que solicita a usted teniendo la esperanza de poder apelar a su buen corazón. Esperamos que usted sea la persona a quien Juan tanto espera.

loans.use: Capital to open a general store and to increase his telephone service.

loans.name: Tereise Punipuao

texts.en:
Tereise Punipuao M., 64, is married with 8 children. She has 10 years of experience in the fishing business. She sells fish to the village and to the general public 5 days per week. She has never had a loan through SPBD.

Tereise expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~208 USD). SPBD loans are Tereise Punipuao’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase a fishing canoe, fishing rods, spears and fishing slippers.

loans.name: Lang

texts.en:
Lang T., 30, lives in Kampong Cham with her husband, Mann Mie, and their two children. She works in a little grocery store business that she owns and typically makes US$2 each day. Her husband is a farmer and spends his days out in the fields, making less than US$1 each day. They have been at these jobs for many years and have been struggling to support themselves and their two young children. Rising inflation has had a devastating impact on many Cambodian families over the course of this past year and Lang T. has been seeking out ways to increase her daily income. She has asked for a loan of US$200 to increase her grocery inventory. She believes that an investment in her grocery business can increase her profits and expand her store. She wants an opportunity to increase her family’s income and improve their standard of living.



Lang T. was unavailable for a photo at the time of the interview, so her husband, Mann Mie, is pictured above.

loans.use: Increase grocery inventory

loans.name: Tautala

texts.en:
Tautala S., 41, is married with 4 children. She has 10 years of experience in the fishing business. She sells fish in the village and to the general public 5 days per week. Her husband helps her with the business.

Tautala has never had a loan through SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (~250 USD). SPBD loans are Tautala’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use the loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment

loans.name: Vang

texts.en: Vang M., 28, is married to Nou Noeun and lives with her young child in Kampong Cham. She works in the fields as a farmer, as she has done for the last 9 years, and makes US$1 each day. Her husband, meanwhile, operates a motortaxi service and typically makes US$2 each day. Rising inflation has made this past year very difficult for many Cambodians and the rural areas have been struggling the most. Vang M. would like to see her income increased and her standard of living improved, but she has lacked the capital to expand her farming business. She has asked for a loan of US$150 to hire a cow to plow her farmland. This will increase the quality and quantity of her harvest this year and can give her an opportunity to increase her income.

loans.use: Hire cow to plow farmland

loans.name: Chin

texts.en: Chin S., 42, is a widow who lives in Kampong Cham with her five children. She has been farming her field for over 25 years and makes less than US$1 each day. Three of her children are also employed and they help to support the family. She has asked for a loan of US$300 to hire a tractor to plow her farmland. With the land that is plowed, she can expect a higher quality and quantity of crops for her harvest. She will have an opportunity to increase her income and improve her standard of living with this investment.

loans.use: Hire a tractor to plow farmland

loans.name: Dourng

texts.en:
Dourng S., 57, is married to Nut Art and lives in Kampong Cham, close to her five children’s families. She has been working in her own little grocery store for many years, making US $2 each day, while her husband works in the fields as a farmer, making less than US $1 each day. Their children are all married and live with their own families now, but two of their daughters work in the local garment factory and help to support the family.

Dourng S. has asked for a loan of US $500 to invest in her grocery store business and to increase her inventory. She believes that this investment can increase her income in the long-term and can allow her to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: Increase grocery inventory

loans.name: Vann

texts.en:
Vann L., 38, works out in the fields as a farmer in Kampong Cham. She lives with her husband, Korn Koeun, and their two young children who are students in the local schools. She typically makes US $1.25 each day, while her husband raises pigs and makes around US $4 each day. The family has been impacted by the rising inflation that has hit Cambodia this past year, and they are looking for ways to diversify and increase their income.

Vann L. has asked for a loan of US $1200 to make a few different investments. She would like to use half the money from the loan to expand her husband’s pig business through the purchase of a few more pigs to raise.

The other half will be used to start a new business. Vann would like to purchase some rice to make rice wine with the other half of the money, and can diversify her sources of income. She sees this investment as a great opportunity for her family to improve its standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase pigs, and also purchase rice to make rice wine.

loans.name: Phhum

texts.en:
Phhum S., 24, lives in Kampong Cham with her husband, Phal Phai, and their young child. She works in the local garment factory each day and typically makes US $1.50, while her husband operates a motortaxi-trailer service and makes US $3 each day.

Her husband drives a motortaxi, but it has an attached trailer on the back that allows him to transport many people at one time. His motorbike, though, is old and in disrepair, so in order to continue running his business and making a good profit, he needs to replace his motorbike. Phhum S. has asked for a loan of US $500 to purchase a new motorbike for her husband.

She believes that this investment can increase her family’s income and give them stability for the future.

loans.use: Replace old motorbike

loans.name: Mit

texts.en:
Mit S. L., 24, sells beef in the local food market, while her husband, Rem Than, raises and sells cattle. They live in Kampong Cham with their young child who attends the local school.

Together her family makes about US $10 of income each day, and they believe that there is a high customer demand and room for their businesses to expand. Mit S. L. has asked for a loan of US $1000 to purchase more cows to expand her husband’s business and increase her family’s income. She believes this investment will help her family in the long-term as well, and it can improve her standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase more cows to resell

loans.name: Thun

texts.en:
Thun P., 37, lives in Kampong Cham with her husband, Eam Koy, and their five children. She works out in the fields, growing rice and vegetables for US $1 each day, while her husband works in construction, making US $2.50 each day. Two of their children are employed, and one is still a student.

All of the children are still living in the home and dependent upon their parents’ income. Thun P. has asked for a loan of US $600 to purchase a motorbike to transport crops to sell at the market. Current public transportation costs have risen rapidly along with gasoline prices and she feels that she can cut down on some unnecessary expenses through this purchase.

With her extra savings, in the future, she would like to raise pigs.

loans.use: Purchase motorbike to transport crops

loans.name: Som

texts.en:
Som M., 46, is married to Brak Chen and lives in Kampong Cham with her three children. Two of her children are students, and the other works in a local garment factory, making US $120 each month.

Som M. owns a little grocery store and typically makes US $3 each day, while her husband works in construction and makes about US $3 each day as well. She has asked for a loan of US $800 to invest in her grocery store business. She would like to increase her inventory and expand her business to meet the growing customer demands. She believes that this investment will allow her to increase her income and improve her family’s standard of living.

Also, Som M. doesn’t view her business expansion as ending with this loan; she would like to see her store grow even further. In the future, she would like to have a much larger grocery store that sells a wider variety of products.

loans.use: Increase grocery inventory

loans.name: Srin

texts.en:
Srin I., 55, is a widow who lives in Kampong Cham with her six children. She works as a rice dealer and makes US $3 each day, while she is also aided by the support of her children who work in the local garment factories or in construction.

One of her children is married and sells both rice and coffee in Phnom Penh. She has had a successful business in Phnom Penh, but lacks the capital necessary to meet the customer demand. Srin I. has asked for a loan of US $1200 to invest in her daughter’s business and to help her set up a shop. The daughter provides a lot of support for the family, and has really helped increase the family’s daily income.

Srin I. believes this investment will reap benefits long into the future and she will be able to see her standard of living increased.

loans.use: Invest in daughter's rice and coffee business

loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Heng B., 44, lives in Kampong Cham with her husband, Pen Sophal, and their two children. She works as a farmer, growing vegetables and selling them in the market for US $5 each day. Her husband works as a construction foreman and typically makes US $7.50 each day. Her husband believes that he can increase his income and expand his business if he had the necessary capital.

Heng B. has asked for a loan of US $1000 to purchase more construction tools for her husband’s business. She looks forward to seeing the results of this investment and seeing how her standard of living can be improved.

loans.use: Purchase construction tools

loans.name: Oun

texts.en:
Oun V., 38, lives in Kampong Cham and sells Khmer noodles in the local market for around US $2 each day. Her husband, Heng Pao Srang, works in construction and typically makes US $2.60 each day. They have five children and one of them works in the local garment factory, providing US $40 each month to support the family.

Oun V. has asked for a loan of US $700 to aid in her husband’s business. He is struggling to provide enough materials to complete his construction projects and needs to purchase some paint, steel, and wood. The family believes that this investment will increase its income and provide an improved standard of living.

Oun V. was unavailable for a photograph at the time of the interview, so her husband, Heng Pao Srang, is pictured above.

loans.use: Purchase supplies to finish construction projects

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Path

texts.en:
Path M., 23, lives in Kampong Cham with her husband, Yem Chamreun, and their one child. She goes to the local food market each morning and sells rice and groceries for US $28 in revenue each day. Her husband works as a security guard and he typically makes US $4 each day.

Path M. and her family has had to endure some difficult times economically in the country of Cambodia. Inflation is high and gas prices influence every single family.

Path M. has desired to expand her business and increase her income, but lacks the capital necessary to do so. She has asked for a loan of US $1000 to purchase more rice to resell and to raise pigs. She believes that by diversifying her income through this new business venture, she will create stability for her future and allow her to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase pigs; and purchase rice to resell.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Koy

texts.en:
Koy S., 54, lives in Kampong Cham with her husband, Chan Art, and three of their children. She takes care of her family and the house, while her husband works in construction every day and makes US $2.50. They have six children, four of whom are married. One of them still lives in the household with his parents. Two children are garment factory workers.

The garment factory workers are able to provide minimal support to the family, but they have been looking for ways to increase their income and improve their current living situation. Koy S. has asked for a loan of US $400 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to begin to operate a motortaxi service in his spare time. This service will provide a little extra income for the family and can give them some stability through providing another source of funds.

The family looks forward to the opportunities available to them with this loan.

loans.use: Purchase motorbike to start taxi service

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Sann

texts.en:
Sann S., 34, sells and collects recyclable materials in Kampong Cham. She typically makes US $7 each day, while her husband, Leang Chhun Heng, works alongside her. They have just recently begun this recycling business, and they are already looking to expand their business to increase profits.

They have four young children in their home, three of whom are students, who require money to support their education. Inflation has been very difficult in Cambodia over the past year and many people are seeking to increase their income to support their families.

Sann S. has asked for a loan of US $600 to purchase a large quantity of recyclable materials to resell for a larger profit. She believes this investment will be a great opportunity for her family and she looks forward to the stability that it can provide for her family.

loans.use: Purchase a greater quantity of recyclable materials

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Fiataua

texts.en: Fiataua L., 30, is married with 5 children.  She has 6 months of experience in the cigarette business. She sells to the village and public people 5 days per week. She has had no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (approximately $145 USD).  SPBD loans are Fiataua’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  This loan will be used for the business.  Her husband also helps out with the business.

loans.use: To buy cartons of cigarettes so that she can sell them loose.

loans.name: Chhean

texts.en:
Chhean H., 46, works with her husband in Kampong Cham. They work out of their home and purchase stone that they use to construct small grinding mills. They typically make US $3 each day and have been constructing mills for the last eight years. They have five children, two of whom are still living at home and who help to support the family with their income.

Chhean H. has asked for a loan of US $500 to purchase more stone to increase her mill production. She believes that together with her husband, she can easily meet the demands of her customers by increasing her production. She sees this loan as an opportunity for business expansion and looks forward to the long-term benefits. Chhean H. was unavailable for a photograph at the time of the interview, so her husband, Kub Hang, is pictured here above.

loans.use: Purchase stone to build mills

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Thy

texts.en:
Thy R., 27, lives with her husband, Sean Ly, in Kampong Cham with their two young children. She travels to the local food market each day to sell fruit and typically makes US $3.30 each day. Her husband works as a motortaxi driver and can typically make US $5 each day, although high gas prices are steadily cutting into his profits.

They R. would like to expand her fruit stand business, but lacks the necessary capital when she is struggling to support her family. She has asked for a loan of US $500 to purchase more fruis to sell in the market. She looks forward to the opportunities provided by this investment and believes in the sustainability of this expansion.

loans.use: Purchase a large quantity of fruits to resell

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Meas

texts.en:
Meas S., 64, is a widow who lives in Kampong Cham and sells clothes in the local market. She has been selling clothes for about seven years now and typically makes US $15 of revenue each day. Inflation has been a struggle for many Cambodians over the past year and people have been forced to find ways to increase their income to meet the rising costs.

Meas S. has asked for a loan of US $1000 to purchase more clothes to resell and believes that this investment will benefit her business in the long-term.

loans.use: Purchase more clothes to resell

loans.name: Kim

texts.en:
Kim C., 37, lives in Kampong Cham with her husband, Len Em, and their four children. She works out in her field as a farmer and makes US $1.25 each day. Her husband is a traditional musician. Three of their children commute to Phnom Penh for work each day and high gas prices have made public transportation costs unbearable.

Kim C. has asked for a loan of US $300 to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work each day and cut down on public transportation expenses. She believes this investment can improve her ability to support her family and can improve her standard of living through savings.

loans.use: Purchase motorbike for commute to work

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Ban

texts.en:
Ban K. H., 33, lives in Kampong Cham with her husband, Sean Sophal, and their five children. She works in the local church and makes US $1.60 each day, while her husband works as a construction foreman and typically makes US $3 each day. He has been in construction for about five years now and desires to see his business expanded to reach more customers. He has difficulties, though, because he cannot purchase the tools or materials that he needs to complete more projects, because he lacks the necessary capital to expand his business.

Ban K. H. has asked for a loan of US $400 to purchase some construction tools and materials for her husband's business, and she believes that their income can be increased through this investment.

loans.use: Purchase construction tools

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Ana

texts.en: Ana F., 67, is married with 12 children.  She has 1 year year of experience in the pancake/porkbun business. She sells to the village and public people 5 days per week. She has had no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (approximately $125 USD).  SPBD loans are Ana’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  This loan will be used for the business.  Her husband also helps out with the business.

loans.use: To purchase flour, sugar and a big frying pan

loans.name: Tineimane

texts.en: Tinemane F., 32, is married with 2 children.  She has 8 months of experience in the pancake, ice pop and popcorn business. She sells to the village and public people 5 days per week. She has had no previous loans with SPBD.  This will be her first.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (approximately $125 USD).  SPBD loans are Tinemane’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  This loan will be used for the business to buy flour, paper cups and popcorn.  Her husband also helps out with the business.

loans.use: To buy flour, paper cups and popcorn

loans.name: Uok

texts.en:
Uok K. N., 52, lives in Kampong Cham with her husband, Cheav Thor, and their four children. She has been traveling around her community and selling traditional Khmer cakes for about seven years now, and typically makes US$4 each day. Her husband works as a farmer and other people will hire him to come and plow their lands for about US$10 each day.

Two of their children work in the local garment factory and help to support the family with US$200 each month. The family has many members to support and it has been very difficult to have a consistent income, because their tractor is old and in disrepair.

Uok K. N. has asked for a loan of US$1000 to purchase a new tractor for her husband to continue running his business. She sees this investment as having long-term benefits and looks forward to the increased income that her family can receive.

loans.use: Purchase a tractor

loans.name: Vainalepa

texts.en: Vainalepa T., 33, is married with 2 children.  She has 3 years years of experience in the vegetable garden business. She sells to the village and public people 3 days per week. She has had 2 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (approximately $145 USD).  SPBD loans are Vainalepa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  This loan will be used for the business.  Her husband also helps out with the business.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizers and also for home improvements

loans.name: Rasela

texts.en: Rasela T., 28, is married with 3 children.  She has 4yrs years of experience in the pancake business. She sells to the village and public people 3 days per week. She has had 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (approximately $145 USD).  SPBD loans are Rasela’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. This loan will be used for the business.  Her husband also helps out with the business.

loans.use: To purchase a frying pan, flour and sugar

loans.name: Lina

texts.en: Lina A., 50, is married with 8 children.  She has 5 years of experience in the fishing business. She sells to the village and public people 5 days per week. She has had 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (approximately $145 USD).  SPBD loans are Lina’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. This loan will be used for the business.  Her husband also helps out with the business.

loans.use: Fishing canoe, goggles and spears

loans.name: Elena

texts.en: Elena M., 51, is married with 5 children.  She has 2 years of experience in the popcorn business. She sells to the village and public people 5 days per week. She has had no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (approximately $125 USD).  SPBD loans are Elena’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. This loan will be used for the business.  Her husband also helps out with the business.

loans.use: To buy popcorn to sell and also for home improvements

loans.name: Lun

texts.en:
Lun S., 26, has two young children and lives in Kampong Cham with her husband, Suon Seang Ly. She is a farmer. She typically pays to harvest a plot of land, and then sells the vegetables in the local food market for around US$2.70 each day.

Her husband sells large amounts of ice to a variety of local businesses and typically makes US$3.80 each day. Lun S. would like to increase her daily income to better support her young family, by investing in her vegetable business. She has asked for a loan of US$1200 to purchase a larger piece of property from which she can harvest yams. In this type of farming system, she will not actually own the land, but will pay to harvest a portion of the land and sell it in the market to make a profit.

She appreciates the opportunities that this loan provides for her family and is looking forward to reaping the benefits of her investment.

loans.use: Invest in yam business

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mom M., 41, lives in Kampong Cham with her husband, Khim Kuy, and five of their children. She goes to the local market each day and sells vegetables for about US$1.60 each day, while her husband works in construction and typically makes US$2 per day. Three of their daughters are also employed, and contribute some money each month from their work in the garment factories.

Despite these five sources of income, though, inflation and other economic difficulties require Mom M. to look for other ways to increase her family's income to support them. In an effort to diversify her family's income and create more economic stability, Mom M. has asked for a loan of US$700 to purchase a motorbike for her husband. With the new motorbike, he can operate a motortaxi service in his spare time after his construction work. She believes this investment can be of great benefit to her family and is optimistic about her future.

loans.use: Purchase a motorbike to run a taxi service

loans.name: Oeun

texts.en:
Oeun C., 41, has been selling rice and porridge in the local market for the last three years. She lives in Kampong Cham with her husband, Duon Somol, and their three young children who are all in school. She typically makes US$5 each day, while her husband operates a motor taxi service and can usually make US$3 each day. High gas prices have recently hindered many taxi services and have made it difficult to access customers.

In an effort to increase her family's income and improve their economic situation, Oeun C. has asked for a loan of US$1000. She will use the money to invest in her food business, which the family believes may be the more stable of the two businesses. She hopes to reach more customers and increase her profits with this investment. Oeun is optimistic about the future.

loans.use: Invest in rice and porridge business

loans.name: Mehriniso

texts.en:
A. Mehriniso is 38 years old, and married. Her husband is pictured in her place. She sells toys for children, and has been renting a small store to run her business for the past 6 years. Her business is the main source of income for her family. Because she has few competitors, Mehriniso’s business is doing very well.

Mehriniso has always wanted her own store to run her business from, and in order to do so, she would like a loan of $600 to improve her business and raise her profits. She would use her earnings to not only support her family, but also realize her goal of having her own store to sell from.

loans.use: Purchasing of the children toys for increasing the range of goods.

loans.name: Rashid

texts.en:
C. Rashid is 30 years old, married, and has four children. He has been selling spare bicycle parts in the local market for the past 7 years. He began his business with a loan from IMON, and was gradually able to build up a permanent customer base and increase the variety of goods he sold. Since 2007, his profits have increased by three times, and he believes that the loans have had a significantly positive impact upon his business.

Rashid has used his earnings to improve his family’s living conditions, and is doing his best to meet all of his children’s needs. He would like to request a loan of $900 in order to purchase spare parts for bicycles and increase the range of his goods, and use the profits to continue to support and contribute to his family.

loans.use: Purchasing of the spare parts for bicycles in order to increase the range of goods for selling

loans.name: Mavlyuda

texts.en:
D. Mavlyuda is 50 years old, married, and has 2 children. Her husband recently left for Russia in order to attain a higher income to support the family. Mavlyuda is currently a market vendor, and has been selling vegetables for the past five years. Her eldest son helps Mavlyuda with the family business. Every day, in the early morning, she purchases fresh vegetables from local farmers and sells them, wholesale, in the market. She is well known for her attractive prices and high quality.

Mavlyuda’s earnings in the market allow her to generate a stable family life. However, she would like to be able to send her children to school, and allow them to attain a higher education. She would like a loan of $300 in order to expand her range of goods and help finance and education for her children.

loans.use: Increasing of the range of vegetables.

loans.name: Uktam

texts.en:
Fozilom Uktam is 28 years old, married, and has two children. Since 2007, he has been selling and repairing bicycles. He currently has a trading post in the local market, and sells various parts of different bicycles. When Fozilom began his business, he had little capital and had to request a loan in order to begin his business. Thanks to his first loan, he established a strong client base and sales have been steady since.

Fozilom would like to expand his business even further by increasing his inventory, and widening his customer base. In order to do so, he is requesting for a loan of $600 in order to purchase additional spare parts, and he would use the profits to further enrich his business.

loans.use: Purchasing of the spare parts for bicycles for increasing the range of goods

loans.name: Bibinor

texts.en:
H. Bibinor is 48 years old, married, and has five children. Her husband works as a farmer. In order to improve the family situation, Bibinor started her own business 7 years ago. She began by baking a national bread, lepeshka, from her home. Her daughter helps her with the business. She is able to sell the majority of her products from her own home, but is also looking to expand and sell in the local markets.

Bibinor would like a loan of $450 in order to purchase the necessary ingredients required for her business. She dreams of sending her children to the University and giving them a good education, and would use the profits from her business to acquire that goal. Bibinor would be grateful, and promises to return her loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: Purchasing the flour as a wholesale for baking the national bread “lepeshka”.

loans.name: Pelenatete

texts.en: Pelenatete L., 38, is married with 5 children.  She has 3 years of experience in the pancake business. She sells to the village and public people 5 days per week. She has had no previous loans with SPBD.  This will be her first.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (approximately $125 USD).  SPBD loans are Pelenatete’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. This loan will be used for the business.  Her husband also helps out with the business.

loans.use: To buy flour and also for home improvements

loans.name: Pelenatete

texts.en: Pelenatete L., 70, is married with 5 children.  She has 4 years of experience in the shop business. She sells to the village and public people 5 days per week. She has had no previous loans with SPBD.  This will be her first.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala (approximately $83 USD).  SPBD loans are Pelenatete’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  This loan will be used for the business.  Her husband also helps out with the business.

loans.use: Buy stocks for the shop

loans.name: Eseta

texts.en: Eseta P., 30, is married with 5 children.  She has 3 years of experience in the pork bun business.  She sells to the village and public people 5 days per week.  She has had no previous loans with SPBD.  This will be her first.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (approximately $104 USD).  SPBD loans are Eseta’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  This loan will be used for the business.  Her husband also helps out with the business.

loans.use: Purchase flour, turkey tail, gripping oil, salt, and soy sauce

loans.name: Fazlidin

texts.en: A. Fazlidin is 21 years old. He has been a farmer since he was 18. He has been working for the past 3 years, and has used his income to support himself and his family. He grows a variety of vegetables and produce, including tomatoes, potatoes, carrots, and cabbage. Fazlidin has made plans this year to attend the University, and due to a slow planting season, needs money to jump-start his crops. He would then use the money earned from his crops to attend University, and acquire a higher education.

loans.use: Purchasing of the seeds and mineral fertilizer.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria T., 44, is married with 7 children.  She has 5 years of experience in the fishing business. She sells to the village and public people 5 days per week. She has had 4 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (approximately $166 USD).  SPBD loans are Maria’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  This loan will be used for the business.  Her husband also helps out with the business.

loans.use: Buy a canoe, spears and other fishing equipment

loans.name: Fazlidin

texts.en: A. Fazlidin is 21 years old. He is single with no children. He has been farming since he was 18. He has 3 years of experience, and has been able to support himself and his family by learning how to take care and manage his crops in the short growing season. His business includes growing and selling of vegetables such as: tomato, onion, potato, cucumber, carrot, cabbage. Thus due to the beginning of the sowing season he is planning to sow onion, potato and cabbage. Fazlidin would like to use this loan to purchase more farming implements such as seeds, mineral fertilizers and other necessities in order to appropriately manage his crops and in the end to make a good profit as in the nearest future he is planning to arrange his wedding by himself . Fazlidin is counting on your help. With your help he can achieve his goals.

loans.use: Purchasing of the seeds and mineral fertilizer.

loans.name: Leua

texts.en: Leua S., 52, is married with 8 children.  She has 5 years of experience in the sewing business. She sells to the village and public people 5 days per week. She has had 2 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (approximately $187 USD).  SPBD loans are Leua’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  This loan will be used to purchase items for her business.

loans.use: Sewing machine ,threads and children's school fees

loans.name: Galo

texts.en: Galo S., 23, is married with children.  She has many years of experience in the groceries business. She sells to the villagers/public 7 days per week. She has had 4 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (approximately $166 USD).  SPBD loans are Gogo’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase sacks of rice, flour, sugar, snacks and salt

loans.name: Kumrikhon

texts.en:
S. Kumrikhon is 47 years old. She is married with four children, and one of her sons is pictured here in her place. Because of a difficult living condition and the fact that her husband left for Russia to earn a higher income, Kumrikhon is facing hard financial times. She currently sells produce and fruits in the local village market, and has been doing so for the past six years.

Every morning at 5 AM Kumrikhon purchases vegetables from local farmers, and sells them wholesale at the market. She is well known not only for her good service, but also her fair prices. Because of this, she is able to generate a steady income and help support her family.

Kumrikhon would like to borrow $450 in order to expand and maintain her business. She has had an excellent loan history in the past, and is sure that she can repay her credit in 12 months.

loans.use: Increasing of the range of fruits and vegetables for selling

loans.name: Mehriniso

texts.en:
T. Mehriniso is 46 years old, married, and has four children. Both of her daughters are married and financially independent, while her sons still live with the family. Mehriniso’s husband works as an entrepreneur.

Mehriniso has been running a drug store for the past 12 years. She sells certified medicines in the center of town, which allows her to access a wide range of clients and customers.

Mehriniso would like to request a loan of $450 in order to increase her business. Her son is about to marry, and she needs the extra income to ensure that the marriage and new family succeeds. Mehriniso is a driven and organized individual, and is sure that she will be able to repay the loan in 4 months.

loans.use: Purchasing medicaments for expanding the business

loans.name: Eshmumin

texts.en:
T. Eshmumin is 54 years old, married, and has five children. In addition, he also has several wonderful grandchildren. Despite his old age, Eshmumin has been involved in bicycle repair since 2007. His business has gradually expanded, and customers continuously return because of his hard-working and polite nature. His clientele is extremely satisfied with their products, and the income Eshmumin earns is a major factor of his family’s income.

Eshmumin would like to request a loan of $600 in order to purchase spare parts for bicycles and increase his repair capabilities. He expresses his gratitude and thanks everyone who will support him in advance, and promises to return his loan on time.

loans.use: Purchasing of the spare parts for bicycle for increasing the range of goods

loans.name: Bibiniso

texts.en: G. Bibniso is 23 years old. She has been running her own business for six years to support her parents. Bibiniso sells a variety of accessories and hair products for women in the local market. She would like to expand her business, and open her own store to establish contacts with constant supplies of well known producers. Bibiniso would like a loan of $1000 to increase the range of goods she sells, and increase her profits to support her family.

loans.use: Purchasing the goods for selling in order to increase the range of goods

loans.name: Yegana

texts.en: Yegana (her husband is pictured) was born in 1970. She is a mother of 2 children. The Khasmammadov family lives in Khachmaz town. This family needs a loan of  $1200 to improve their greenhouse. They have been in this business for 7 years.

loans.use: To improve her greenhouse

loans.name: Munavar

texts.en: I. Munavar is 58 years old, married, and has one child. She has been married for 35 years, and her son is married. Munavar’s husband works as an accountant. In order to support her husband, Munavar has been running her own business for the past eight years. She sell national trousers for women, an important article of clothing in Tajikistan. The majority of women wear them, and Munavar is able to sell to them in the central market of Dushanbe city. Munavar would like to expand her customer base and clientele range, and is requesting a loan of $1000. She would use the profits earned from her business to continue to support her family.

loans.use: Purchasing of the new national trousers for women for increasing the range of goods.

loans.name: Inobat

texts.en:
K. Inobat is 35 years old, married, and the mother of two children. Her husband is a taxi-driver. Inobat and her husband have been working hard to ensure that their children have the best possible future. Inobat has been running her own business for ten years, and sells clothes. As her business progressed and she became more involved, Inobat would like to expand and open her own store. Currently, she sells shoes for women in a store located in the central market. She is extremely polite and friendly to her customers, and works hard to ensure they have a pleasant shopping experience. She would like to diversify the range of goods she sells, in order to satisfy her clients’ needs.

Inobat’s income contributes significantly to her family’s budget. However, as her children grow, the financial burden on the family is increasing as well. Inobat would like for her children to continue to learn and have an education, and is requesting a loan of $1000 to increase her selling capacity and range.

loans.use: Purchasing of the new shoes for increasing the range of goods for selling

loans.name: Mavlyuda

texts.en: Masurova Mavlyuda is 58 years old, married, and has four children. All of her children are married and supporting their parents. Her youngest son, Sayfullo, has three children. Mavlyuda has been running her own business for eight years. She sells trousers for women and girls at the local market, and the income she earns contributes significantly to the family’s budget. Mavlyuda would like to purchase a new inventory of trousers to increase her customer base and clientele, and is requesting a loan of $1000. She has had an excellent credit history in the past, and would use the money she earns to further support and contribute to her family.

loans.use: Purchasing the national trousers for women and girls in order to increase the range of goods for selling.

loans.name: Srey

texts.en: Srey K. and her husband are both farmers who live in Prasat Village in Kampong Thom Province. She has two children: one of whom is married, while another is as a garment worker in Phnom Penh City. Mrs. K. wants to reduce transportation costs and she is asking for a loan to purchase a motorcycle for household and business use. The loan will allow her family to reduce expenses and increase business opportunities. The picture is of Mrs. K. and her husband.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Nasiba

texts.en: M. Nasiba is 46 years old. She is married and the loving mother of five children. Her husband is a journalist. Nasiba is a market vendor, and sells footwear and shoes. Nasiba delivers all of her goods with the help of her son. Nasiba strives to purchase quality items and provide them at a reasonable price to her customers, and works hard to ensure her clients are satisfied with their products. Her business is doing well, and her stable income is allowing her to provide her children with many opportunities and a strong education. Nasiba would like to expand the range of shoes she sells to her clients, and would like a loan of $1000. She would use the profits earned to support her family and continue financing her children’s education.

loans.use: Purchasing of the shoes for teenagers in order to increase the range of goods for selling.

loans.name: Guldasta

texts.en:
P. Guldasta is 47 years old. She is married with four children. Seven years ago, Guldasta began a business so she could cover her household expenses, because her husband´s salary was not enough. She decided to start a business selling children’s trousers. As time went by, P. found that selling women’s trousers yielded a larger income. Considering that the national trousers is a very important item for most women and girls of Tajikistan, Guldasta’s business is stable and successful, allowing her to contribute considerably to her family’s income. Currently, Guldasta’s goods are in high demand. She would like to take a chance and increase her inventory. A loan of $1000 would greatly improve her stock of clothes, and allow her to expand her customer base.

The well-being of this family is in your hands. Help them by contributing to the growth of her business, and they will sincerely thank you.

loans.use: Purchasing the national trousers for women and girls in order to increase the range of goods for selling.

loans.name: Him

texts.en: Mrs. Him T. is a farmer and her husband is a horse cart taxi driver. They both live in Prasat Village in Kampong Thom Province. She has a daughter who works as a garment worker in Phnom Penh. Mrs. T. is asking for a loan to purchase a pig to raise. She hopes to use the remainder of the loan to purchase fertilizer for her rice crop. She hopes the loan will allow her to increase her family’s income.

loans.use: To purchase a pig and fertilizer

loans.name: Navy

texts.en:
Mrs. Navy C. is a palm sugar middlewoman in Kveth Village in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. Navy is also a pig breeder. Since both her business activities are doing well, she would like to expand them. Therefore, she asked for a loan to buy palm sugar and to buy more piglets for breeding.

Navy is a 33-year-old widow with a child who is enrolled in a local school.

loans.use: To expand her palm sugar sales and pig breeding businesses.

loans.name: Vichara

texts.en:
Vichara K. is a villager in Kveth Village in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. She is a garment worker. Her husband, Yan Keo (also pictured), is a farmer and construction worker. Despite all their efforts, their living conditions are not very good; thus Vichara decided to launch a business breeding pigs.

Vichara will use her loan to buy piglets for breeding and to build a new house so they can live independently from her parents.

loans.use: To buy piglets for breeding and build a house.

loans.name: Yoeurn

texts.en:
Mrs. Yoeurn P. sells Khmer noodles in Roka Tong Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Her husband, Mr. Him Nao (pictured, on the right), is a rice farmer and sells firewood. They have eight children, one of whom also sells firewood and another who helps in the rice field. Four are attending the local school while the remaining two are too young to work or study.

Usually Mr. Him Nao hires a laborer with cows to plow his rice plantation, but now he would like to start working the field himself, which is more economically viable. Thus, Him and Yoeurn decided to apply for a loan to buy buffaloes to use as draft animals.

loans.use: To buy buffalo to plow her rice field.

loans.name: Din

texts.en: Mrs. Din K. is a farmer and her husband is a horse cart taxi driver. They both live in Prasat Village in Kampong Thom Province. They have four children: three of whom are working for a garment factory in Phnom Penh City, while one of her sons is a construction worker. Mrs.K. is asking for a loan to purchase a motorcycle for work and household use. This loan will allow her to reduce transport expenses and improve business activities.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Kheng

texts.en:
Mrs. Kheng P. is a 32-year-old widow from Roka Tong Village in the Kampong Chhnang Province of Cambodia, where her child is enrolled in the local school. She is a rice middle-woman who buys rice to keep in stock and re-sell later at a better price. 

Kheng's business activity works well, and she wants to expand it. Thus, Kheng is requesting a loan to buy more rice to keep in stock.

loans.use: Buy more rice stock.

loans.name: Galamshah

texts.en: Galamshah was born in 1956. He is married and has 3 children. This family lives in Khachmaz town. Three years ago, he started selling agricultural produce. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy fruits and vegetables to improve his business,

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Yim

texts.en: Mrs. Yim S. is a primary school teacher and a farmer. Her husband is a principle of another primary school. Their combined income is $4.80 per day which remains insufficient to support her family’s expenses sufficiently. Mrs. Yim needs to expand her farming business in order to increase her income. Therefore, she would like to ask for a loan to purchase a plot of farmland for her farming business. The loan will allow them to expand their farming business and help increase their family’s income.

loans.use: To purchase a plot of farmland

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Mrs. Keo H. and her husband are both farmers who live in Prasat Village in Kampong Thom Province. They have four children of which two of whom are married. One is currently single and working as a garment factory worker. Mrs. H. is asking for a loan to purchase a pump machine for her farming business. The loan will allow them improve their farming business and raise their family’s income.

loans.use: To purchase a pump machine to use for farming business

loans.name: Ny

texts.en:
Mr. Ny M., 45, and his wife, Mrs. Yam Ly, 54, were married in 1985 and have eight children: six sons and two daughters. Two of their children are fishermen, one child is a driver, one is garment factory worker, one daughter assist her mother selling gruel and the last three children are in school. The family lives live along National Road number five about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Mr. Ny has been in the business of selling wood charcoal for fifteen years. He buys the charcoal from Kampong Speu province for resale in Phnom Penh. Mrs. Yam Ly sells gruel in the village. Ny carries wood charcoal by his Motor Remoque trailer, but his trailer is a bit small and he needs to a bigger one.

Mr. Ny is requesting a loan of US$800 to purchase a new trailer to replace the old one.

loans.use: To purchase a new trailer to replace the old one

loans.name: Filéra

texts.fr:
Born in 1959 in Kabou in the Bassar prefecture, Mrs. Filéra B. is married and has two children. She is a courageous woman who sells firewood in Lomé. She has been doing this for more than 20 years and her main customers are bakers and local beverage producers. She buys wood wholesale or buys a tree trunk that she has cut up by lumberjacks. It is a very active business for her, but due to a lack of means, she is unable to meet customer demand. This is the second loan she has requested for this project, and she will use the money to buy 60 bundles of wood so she can satisfy her customers’ demands.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

Née en 1959 à kabou dans la préfecture de Bassar, madame B. Filéra est mariée et a deux enfants. Elle est une femme vaillante qui exerce le commerce de vente de bois de chauffe à lomé. Elle mène cette activité depuis plus de 20 ans et a pour principaux clients les boulangers et les fabricants de boissons locales. Elle achète en gros ou achète un tronc d’arbre qu’elle fait scier par les spécialistes. C’est un commerce très florissant mais faute de moyens elle n’arrive pas à être à la hauteur de sa clientèle. A travers ce projet, elle sollicite ce second crédit pour acheter 60 fagots de bois afin de pouvoir satisfaire tous ses clients.

loans.use: Purchase of 60 bundles of wood

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for WAGES - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey C., 54, and her husband, Mr. Morn Tem, 45, were married in 1979 and have eleven children: seven sons and four daughters. Two of their children are married and live outside the family home. The family lives live along National Road number five about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Mrs. Srey and her husband have been farming and fishing since 1980. The fish they catch in the lake by their village is sold at Prek Phnao market about five kilometers from their home. They also grow rice on a farm a bit far from their home.

Mrs. Srey is requesting a loan of US$500 to purchase one boat and fishing nets to expand their fishing business.

loans.use: To purchase one boat and fishing nets

loans.name: Thach

texts.en:
Mrs. Thach P. is widow with five children: two sons and three daughters. One of her sons is married and lives outside the family home. All of her daughters work in a garment factory. The family lives in a Phnom Penh suburb.

Mrs. Thach has been selling boiled eggs and grilled beef at her home for over one year. All of her daughters work a bit far from ,so they need to travel by motor taxi, which costs a lot of money. Thach wants to buy a motorcycle for her daughters to drive to work, so they can save on transportation costs. She is requesting a loan of US$700 to purchase a motorcycle.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her daughters to drive to work.

loans.name: Chhum

texts.en: Mr. Chhum B. is a fisherman from Thnort Village in Kampong Thom Province. His wife is a fish-paste seller in the market and they have three children, all of whom are in school. Due to a growing fishing industry, B. is asking for a loan to purchase more fishing equipment. The loan will help him expand his business and hopefully increase his family’s income. B.'s wife and daughters are pictured.

loans.use: To purchase more fishing equipment

loans.name: Phalla

texts.en:
Mr. Phalla P., 52, and his wife, Mrs. Viti Chhorn, 48, live along national road number one about eighteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1979 and have five children, one son and four daughters. Two of their children have full time employment. One daughter is a Khmer traditional dancer. One daughter is married, and the youngest one is in school.

Mr. Phalla has been a mason since 1983. He does his work in the village and a near by province, while his wife stay at home take care of the children. The couple is repairing their house and Phalla is requesting a loan of $1000 to finish the project.

loans.use: To repair his house.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Kokou

texts.fr:
Mr. Kokou A. was born in Gbatopé in the Zio prefecture on December 31, 1986. He is married and has two children. From a young age he learned how to make shoes because he had a passion for it. Since 1993, he has operated a shoemaking shop in the city of Lomé where he purchases, on-site, everything that he needs to make shoes. He takes orders and also sells his shoes at expositions. His shoes are in high demand, but due to his insufficient working capital, he is unable to meet customer demand. Therefore, he got the idea to take out his first loan to increase his working capital so he can buy raw materials to make shoes, such as lizard skins, soles, and buffalo hides.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

Monsieur A. Kokou est né à Gbatopé dans la préfecture de Zio le 31 décembre 1986. Il est marié et père de 2 enfants. Dès son jeune age il a apprit ce métier de fabrication de chaussures car c’était sa passion. Depuis 1993, il a ouvert son atelier de fabrication dans la ville de Lomé où il achète sur place tout le nécessaire pour la fabrication. Il reçoit des commandes et fait aussi la vente par exposition. Ses chaussures sont très demandées, mais à cause de son fonds de roulement qui n’est pas très suffisant il n’arrive pas à répondre à cette demande. Il a eu alors l’idée de prendre ce premier crédit pour augmenter son fonds de roulement afin d’acheter les matières premières qui sont les peau de varan, les semelles et les bifalo.

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials for making shoes

loans.name: Sophorn

texts.en:
Mr. Sophal U., 35, and his wife, Mrs. Ny Khen, 39, live along national road number one about eighteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1994 and have two daughters who are in school.   

Mr. Sophal has been a mason since 1995. He does his work in the village and a near by province, while his wife stays at home to care for the children. The couple is repairing their house, and Sophal is requesting a loan of $1200 to repair his house and buy construction material to expand his business.

loans.use: To repair his house and buy construction materials

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Davit

texts.en:
Mr. Davit P., 31, and his wife, Mrs. Sokden Yem, 27, live along National Road Number six about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 2001 and have two sons.

Mr. Davit and his wife have a new restaurant business. In the evenings, they sell soup and grilled meat in a small shelter in front of their house.
